Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Pellet based 3D print extrusion process for shoe manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is aimed at developing a novel cost-effective 3D printing process to manufacture shoes. Currently shoes are mass manufactured, typically overseas, using fixed molds that do not optimally meet the need of an individual. 3D printing of shoes offers the promise of providing individual customization tailored not just to fit, style, and colors, but to individual biomechanics and medical needs, the latter of which are being poorly met with mass manufactured shoes. However, a number of technical challenges exist to make 3D printing of shoes sufficiently cost-effective that it can be provided beyond just a select few individuals. This project develops a novel and cost-effective 3D printing process to manufacture components of shoes, using readily available and recyclable thermoplastic pellets. This novel 3D printing process will enable the manufacture of new, innovative shoe designs that cannot be made with any other manufacturing process. Additionally, it will make mass customization of shoes a reality, providing access to healthy customizable shoes for many individuals. Unlike traditional manufacturing processes currently being done overseas, this novel manufacturing technology is very amenable to implementing in the United States on a local level. Thus, this project will not only help move shoe manufacturing back to the United States, generating income for tax revenue, it will create new high-tech jobs in manufacturing.


This project develops a novel 3D printing technology to print a proprietary mix of elastomeric type material developed based on years of published research of the biomechanical effects of footwear by the proposer. The primary innovation proposed is a miniature-sized plasticizing screw-based extruder that reliably and consistently extrudes all types of elastomeric type material including foam, the latter of which, to our knowledge, has never before been 3D printed. Previous attempts using a simple auger instead of a true plasticizing screw have produced inconsistent and unreliable results. The goal is to develop a reliable miniaturized screw-based extruder, integrated into a specially constructed 3D printer sized to make a pair of shoes, whereby pellets are fed through a hopper. The extruder-printer design will be based on unique experience in extruding elastomeric types of materials and will be evaluated for reliability and consistency in a specially instrumented 3D printer. This technology if successful, will allow for a novel manufacturing process where a bank of 3D printers operate simultaneously, each producing their own made-to-order pair of shoes and/or shoe components. This system will offer the potential for a cost-effective footwear solution that is customized not only to fit, but to an individual's specific biomechanical and medical needs. Additionally, it will allow for the creation of novel healthy designs based on the proposer's research that cannot be made with any other manufacturing process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrated the feasibility of a novel 3D printing technology to print a mix of elastomeric material that is most suitable for footwear based on the principal investigator’s research on the biomechanical effects of footwear. A miniature-sized plasticizing screw-based extruder was successfully designed, constructed and demonstrated to be feasible in printing this elastomeric material from its readily available, cost-effective, and recyclable form: thermoplastic pellets. An instrumented 3D printer was constructed and algorithms were developed to test the consistency and reliability of miniaturized extruder design iterations that were based on industrial extrusion and injection molding designs used for processing elastomers. The project was successful in developing a highly effective screw-based extruder design that consistently and reliably printed without any of the typical failures seen with traditional 3D printing using filament, such as inconsistent feeding, kinking, and jamming. The project also was successful in demonstrating the feasibility of using blowing agents and microcellular expanding agents in conjunction with pellets, to produce novel cellular and foamed material that cannot be made with any other 3D printing process. The instrumented printer and algorithms were critical to developing the optimal pellet extruder design for printing consistently and reliably. The data from the instrumented printer also informed the design of a novel spring-loaded shut-off valve that was constructed and demonstrated to be feasible in eliminating drool from the end of the nozzle. This is significant insofar as drool from the end of the nozzle is a pervasive problem in 3D printing affecting the quality of the print.

While 3D printing footwear offers the promise of mass customization, a number of technical challenges have kept it from being used beyond for just a select few individuals. This project successfully addressed many of these technical challenges to make the possibility of 3D printing of footwear sufficiently cost-effective such that it can be broadly used. The demonstration in this project of reliably and consistently 3D printing elastomeric material from cost-effective, recyclable pellets could make the promise of mass customization of footwear a reality, providing individual customization tailored not just to fit, style, and colors, but also to an individual’s biomechanics and/or medical needs. Additionally, it could allow for the creation of novel materials and new innovative healthy footwear designs based on biomechanical research that cannot be made with any other manufacturing process. The project outcomes support that this manufacturing process could become something of a game changer in the shoe industry, truly delivering the promise of mass customization, using recyclable and readily available thermoplastic materials. Unlike traditional manufacturing processes currently being done overseas, this novel manufacturing technology is very amenable to implementing in the United States on a local level. Thus, this technology would not only help move footwear manufacturing back to the United States, generating income for tax revenue, it would create entirely new clean, safe jobs in manufacturing. Finally, beyond footwear, this novel 3D printing process could be employed in the manufacturing of many other goods as well.

 


Last Modified: 06/30/2017
Modified by: D.Casey Kerrigan

An instrumented 3D printer was constructed and algorithms were developed to test the consistency and reliability of miniaturized extruder design iterations that were based on industrial extrusion and injection molding designs used for processing elastomers. The project was successful in developing a highly effective screw-based extruder design that consistently and reliably printed without any of the typical failures seen with traditional 3D printing using filament, such as inconsistent feeding, kinking, and jamming. The project also was successful in demonstrating the feasibility of using blowing agents and microcellular expanding agents in conjunction with pellets, to produce novel cellular and foamed material that cannot be made with any other 3D printing process. The instrumented printer and algorithms were critical to developing the optimal pellet extruder design for printing consistently and reliably. The data from the instrumented printer also informed the design of a novel spring-loaded shut-off valve that was constructed and demonstrated to be feasible in eliminating drool from the end of the nozzle. This is significant insofar as drool from the end of the nozzle is a pervasive problem in 3D printing affecting the quality of the print. The demonstration in this project of reliably and consistently 3D printing elastomeric material from cost-effective, recyclable pellets could make the promise of mass customization of footwear a reality, providing individual customization tailored not just to fit, style, and colors, but also to an individual?s biomechanics and/or medical needs. Additionally, it could allow for the creation of novel materials and new innovative healthy footwear designs based on biomechanical research that cannot be made with any other manufacturing process. The project outcomes support that this manufacturing process could become something of a game changer in the shoe industry, truly delivering the promise of mass customization, using recyclable and readily available thermoplastic materials.
